title: Telesat to order 100 fewer satellites for LEO constellation
summary: TAMPA, Fla. — Increasing costs and delays have forced Telesat to downsize plans for 298 low Earth orbit satellites by a third to keep within its $5 billion budget.

title: Virgin Galactic pushes back commercial suborbital flights to 2023
summary: Virgin Galactic is again postponing the start of commercial service of its SpaceShipTwo suborbital spaceplane from late 2022 to early 2023, blaming the latest delay on supply chain and labor issues.

title: SpaceX moved NROL-85 from the Cape to Vandenberg at no extra cost, in exchange for reusing booster
summary: The NRO and SpaceX worked out a deal to move NROL-85 to the West Coast at no extra cost to the government and in exchange the NRO agreed to fly the mission on a reused first stage

title: New Intelsat CEO builds out leadership team
summary: Intelsat announced financial, commercial and aviation leadership changes May 5 to guide the satellite operator’s post-bankruptcy future.

title: NASA Administrator to Visit Florida Students, Industry
summary: NASA Administrator Bill Nelson will speak to elementary school students about the future of space exploration Monday, May 9, and tour a lab working on robotic construction technologies Tuesday, May 10, during a trip to Florida.

title: NASA planning next SLS countdown rehearsal in June
summary: NASA expects to be ready to perform another countdown rehearsal of the Space Launch System in early June as it pushes back the first launch of the vehicle to at least August.

title: Rocket Report: Virgin Galactic delayed again, June targeted for next SLS test
summary: "Our teams are containing the majority of these issues to minimize impact on schedules."

title: SpaceX launches morning Starlink mission from Kennedy Space Center
summary: SpaceX launched 53 internet communication satellites to low Earth orbit on the Starlink Group 4-17 mission. With liftoff scheduled for 09:42 UTC (5:42 AM EDT), the Falcon 9 launched from historic Launch Complex 39A (LC-39A). This mission marked SpaceX’s 18th mission of 2022, making a pace of one Falcon 9 launch every seven days. In the event of a scrub, there was a backup window less than 24 hours later on May 7.

title: SpaceX caps an incredibly busy month with a NASA crew landing Friday morning
NASA, ESA Astronauts Safely Return to Earth
summary: NASA’s SpaceX Crew-3 astronauts aboard the Dragon Endurance spacecraft safely splashed down Friday in the Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Florida, completing the agency’s third long-duration commercial crew mission to the International Space Station.
